captions.text: We have built a virtual, slow-motion camera,
where we can see photons, or light particles, moving
through space. Now you have seen Doc Edgerton's
pictures of a bullet through an apple.
But photons travel about a million times faster
than bullets. So our camera can see these photons,
or bullets of light, traveling through space.
We use a very regular pulsed light source
and a camera, that is not one camera, but an array
of five hundred sensors, each triggered at a
trillionth-of-a second-delay.
So, even though each of our sensors is slow, we
can still capture fast movie.
I'm standing next to our laboratory setup here.
This is our camera, objectives in the front here.
The body of the camera is much larger than what
you would expect from a regular camera,
like the one over here.
Our light source is a titanium-sapphire laser
that's over here, and emits a beam of very, very
short pulses, and those pulses are then directed to
the seam [pause] with these mirrors.
Now, our camera only sees one dimension
so it makes a fast movie, but it makes a fast movie
of one line of the scene only
And in order to fix that, we have these two
mirrors here. We look at the scene via these two
mirrors, and when we rotate this upper mirror here
we actually see different lines of the scene.
So, what's happening is, the camera keeps taking
images and we very slowly rotate this mirror
to scan our field of view across the entire scene.
And because all of our pulses look the same,
we can, in the end, go and combine all of these
images that we took to get one complete movie
of the scene.
Such a camera may be useful in medical imaging
in industrial or scientific use, and in the future
even for consumer photography.
In medical imaging, now we can do ultrasound with
light, because we can analyze how light will scatter
one-dimentionally inside the body.
In industrial imaging, one can use the scattered light
to analyze defects in materials.
And in consumer photography, we are always
fascinated with creating lighting effects that appear
to come from very sophisticated light sources.
But, because we can watch photons seemingly
moving through the space, we can analyze the
transport, the movement, of these photons and
create new photographs as if we had created
those expensive light sources in a studio.

title: Visualizing video at the speed of light — one trillion frames per second

comments.text:
1) "... now we can do ultrasound with light" - Okay, it has been two years. 
LET'S SEE IT!
2) The raw laser images are monochromatic. Where do you get color? Ideally 
you need a red, a green, and a blue laser to get RGB color. (And that's not 
guaranteed to look right.) Subtleties missing from your color sequences 
suggest that you are using single laser image sequences and colorizing them 
by mapping them onto the original photographs.
3) We are not "seeing photons" - the image would look like gravel.﻿

Hello Sir, your innovation is phenomenal and amazing. Helps understanding

camera capturing images at 1 trillion frames per second is actually 
capturing events one trillionth of that second after they happened. So my 
Q1 is does this mean that even a high concentrated beam of laser is 
scattering photons away from its trajectory so they may reach the camera 
and form the image. Q2 is if it does then does this mean the actual packet 
of beam of laser traveling through space relative to observer is 
bigger/longer/brighter/has more energy or anything than it actually appears 
in the camera, as camera is capturing only the photons its receiving and 
making picture out of it. and my last question Q3 is if you fire a single 
photon, no beam, or packet of photons or light but single particle of light 
through absolute vacuum in a pitch dark environment, even then would camera 
capture anything. If yes then how is this happening as photon is not 
changing path then what is creating the picture. If not then does this mean 
that the camera captures images from photons reflected/refracted from some 
object or scattered from light source and in this process loses some 
information as it can capture and process light of certain wavelength.     ﻿

comments.text:
To clarify for people, photons aren't actually a *physical* particle. It's 
a boson, a force. Just like gluons which hold quarks and such together. 
Thus, when you hear that you see the particles of light, you're actually 
seeing the effect of the photon boson. The photon boson represents the 
electromagnetic field, much like the gluon boson represents the strong 
force, and the W & Z bosons represent the weak force. A photon doesn't look 
like anything. It's simply an electromagnetic wave.

Photon boson == EM wave﻿

many laser bursts. So, while *true* high-speed photography is still

comments.text:
+PaladinswordSaurfang Why would the taking of a picture effect the 
wavefunction? I get that everything effects everything else on some level, 
but the taking of a picture is almost entirely passive unless the flash is 
on. The other effect that could be produced is the way it would scatter 
some indirect light from the pulse, but that would be true for any object 
in the room. However, the thing to remember is that the effect the camera 
or any other object would have would have on the waveform, would be uniform 
due to the fact the objects remained static in the room throughout the 
sequence of light pulses.

Maybe I don't understand what you are saying. You do know these pulses 
aren't taking place in rapid succession, but instead over a relatively 
longer time. Meaning the preceding pulse 's waveform completely dissipates 
before the next waveform starts.
comments.author: Chris Newman (Fat Libertarian Dude)

comments.text:
+Feddy Fredrickson
But the effect of photography would collapse a wavefunction. So a single 
pulse of light might actually look different to many pulses because of this.
comments.author: PaladinswordSaurfang

comments.text:
You are right. It is capturing multiple identical events at pico second 
delayed interval captures. Because each pulse of laser light is identical, 
when the captured images are merged into a movie, it is for all accounts a 
perfect representation of a trillion fps camera.

I think it is really neat.

comments.text:
Everything what you see - is light, what reflected from objects into your 
eye. So if i'm able to see speed of light it means, that light already 
reflected in my eyes, so it means light is faster. You cannot see light 
without having light already reflected in your eye. That's fact, beat it. 
Example for dummies: I'm sitting in completely dark room without any light 
turned on and I cannot see anything. In front of me there is light source 
from 10 meters away. Someone turned it on. Light reflected and projected 
into my eyes for 3,33564095198152e-8 seconds. Let's stop time at point when 
beam of light reached only 5 meters. It will take 1,66782047599076e-8 
seconds. So, outside of this beam there will be darkness, because it didn't 
reach it yet. You will see light only in space it reached. So it means if 
you see "speed of light" it already reached your eyes/lenses of camera, and 
that means that light is much faster than your "one trillion frames per 
second". That's it is scientifically impossible to see speed of light. Beat 
it.﻿

comments.text:
The moving spherical surface of light, viewed in real time is just a flash. 
You don't see such things with your naked eyes, unless you're on drugs. 
Seriously. In fact there's no way to illuminate the scene to reproduce such 
lighting using just one light source. And all they have to produce this 
spherical surface of light is a single laser pulse, shining through a 
single lens at the scene.

So, not only you can't see it with your naked eyes, you can't even use a 
single light source to make it look like that unless that light source 
turns on and off ultra fast, and your camera is ultrafast, too.
comments.author: Kuba Ober

comments.text:
Wait, so from what I understand, this is not a single photon traveling in a 
bottle... It's more like capturing a LOT of frames "slices" from a steady 
stream of photons.. So as they rotate the mirror ("slowly", which I assume 
is slower than the speed of light), they get the next "line" of view, which 
is basically the next frame of the video, but it's Not the same photon... I 
hope I understand it correctly... Still a really cool technique though.﻿
comments.author: itai alter

comments.text:
There's no steady stream of photons. The light pulse is so short that it 
has a "small" spatial extent (under an inch!). For comparison, a light 
blinking on and off at 50% duty cycle at 1 blink/second creates a light 
pulse with a spatial extent of 93,000 miles.

comments.author: Alan Ward

comments.text:
It's demonstrably possible. Your 1st assertion is demonstrably false. The 
2nd one and 3rd one are true. The 4th one shows the misunderstanding. It is 
meaningless to compare the *velocity* of light (in units of distance over 
time) to the *imaging rate* (in units of 1 over time). In fact, this very 
technique is just stroboscopy, only done much, much faster.
comments.author: Kuba Ober

comments.text:

object into our eyes? If that's the case, how do we see the pulse of light 
strike the object before it has a chance to bounce off to our eyes?﻿
comments.author: Coradon

comments.text:
I don't understand why that would be a problem. If you listen to a car 
moving past you, you can also "hear" it moving, so that even with closed 
eyes you can tell whether it moved left-to-right or right-to-left or 
whatever, even though you actually perceive the sound waves only when they 
reach your ear. With this camera it would be the same. The fact that the 
reflected photons take longer to move from that coke bottle to the camera 
than the original photons take to move through the bottle from left to 
right doesn't change the fact that the photons that were reflected earlier 
will reach the camera earlier.

It makes no sense to compare the two, so saying that one cannot "exceed" 
another is meaningless. The rate cannot be compared to a speed, so saying 
that it cant "exceed" a speed is like saying goobledygook or wakalixes. 
Gibberish. I don't know what you're trying to say, but so far it doesn't 
make sense. You have to be really careful with your words and what they 
mean. TL;DR: You're very adamant about a statement that doesn't make any 
sense. You must first decide on what would be a sensible statement to make, 
then we can talk some more. So far, you're yelling "blah blah" again and 
again, possibly getting upset that no one understands you. Just stop. We'll 
listen when you stop yelling "blah blah" and start using English again.
comments.author: Kuba Ober

comments.text: The rate of acquisition cannot exceed the speed of light though.
comments.author: Jesusisyhwh

comments.text:
Light has a speed of propagation. In vacuum and air it's about 300,000 
km/s. A camera has a rate of image acquisition. This one's is 1,000,000,000 
images/s. As you can see, the units are different, so trying to compare the 
two is meaningless. This camera's rate of imaging has nothing to do 
whatsoever with the speed of light. It captures whatever light has arrived 
at the image sensor at the moment the sensor is taking the exposure. In 
other words, it would work just as well if the light traveled 10x slower, 
or 10x faster.

It'd help if the snarky commenters were, well, less snarky. We're not all 
privy to good education. Just because I was taught this stuff in grade 
school doesn't make it so for everyone. Now, if Jesusisyhwh was taught this 
and ignored it, scorn would be well-deserved.

comments.author: Mike Conwell

comments.text:
Cluster of photons (pulsed light) passing through a substance in a bottle. 
Photons interact with the substance (absorbed/re-emitted) along the path of 
the beam. Interactions occur according to a distribution curve, most 
continue along the path of the beam whilst some photons end up being 
scattered around. The bottle acts to focus these scattered photons too. 
This happens all the way through the bottle, some photons are being 
deflected towards the camera. Would be good to have confirmation.
comments.author: DuTriDu
